**National Emblem of India**
Video: {video:0mAPyZvvXt4:0}
â–ªï¸ The State Emblem of India is an adaptation of the Lion Capital of Ashoka at Sarnath.
â–ªï¸ It was erected by Ashoka at Sarnath in around 250BC
â–ªï¸ Adopted on 26 January 1950 (the day India became a Republic).
â–ªï¸ It consists of four Asiatic lions standing back-to-back.
â–ªï¸ Out of four lions, only three are visible (the fourth is hidden).

Below the lions, there is a circular base featuring:
A horse on the left.
A bull on the right.
The Dharma Chakra (wheel) in the center.
An elephant and a lion carved on the abacus.

The motto inscribed below in Devanagari script:
â€œSatyameva Jayateâ€ (Truth Alone Triumphs) â€” taken from the Mundaka Upanishad.

It is used on all official documents, currency notes, passports, and government buildings.

**INTRODUCTION**
â–ªï¸ The Indus Valley Civilization was established around 3300 BC 
â–ªï¸ It flourished between 2600 BC and 1900 BC . 
â–ªï¸ It started declining around 1900 BC and disappeared around 1400 BC. 

â–ªï¸ The Indus Valley Civilization is a **Bronze Age Civilization**. ğŸ“Œ 
â–ªï¸The other contemporary civilizations were â€“ Egypt, Mesopotamia, & China.

â–ªï¸ Harappa was the first site of the Indus Valley Civilization to be discovered. ğŸ“Œ 
â–ªï¸ Harappa is located in present-day Punjab, Pakistan, 
â–ªï¸ Due to this, the Indus Valley Civilization is also known as the Harappan Civilization.
â–ªï¸ It was discovered in 1921 by Dayaram Sahni. At that time, Sir John Marshall was the Director of the Archaeological Survey of India.
â–ªï¸ The excavations were carried out under the guidance of Sir John Marshall, the then Director of the Archaeological Survey of India.

â–ªï¸ Mohenjodaro was the largest site of the Harappan Civilization.  ğŸ“Œ

**About Dholavira site:**
â–ªï¸ Dholavira is present in Gujarat, India.
â–ªï¸ It is the only World Heritage Site (WHS) from the Harappan civilization. ğŸ“Œ 
â–ªï¸ It is on the Khadir Beyt (island) in the Rann of Kutch in Gujarat where the famous Luni river flows. 

**Its Unique Feature**
â–ªï¸ In other sites, the city is divided into two parts, and each is surrounded by brick walls. However, in Dholavira, the city is divided into **three parts**, each surrounded by stone walls.
â–ªï¸ In other places, pictographic script was mainly found on seals, but in Dholavira, pictographic script was found written on **stones** and perhaps on wood.
â–ªï¸ It also has **water reservoirs** ğŸ“Œ

**About Lothal site**
â–ªï¸ Lothal site is present on the bank of river Bogava, which is a tributary of river Sabarmati in Gujurat. 

**Important discoveries at Lothal**
â–ªï¸ Warehouse: to store grains
â–ªï¸ Fire Alter

blocks.string: Economy

children.string:
â–ªï¸ The people of the Harappan civilization practiced agriculture. 
â–ªï¸ Evidence from Kalibangan in Rajasthan, where terracotta plough toys were found, suggests the use of bulls or cattle for ploughing. 
â–ªï¸ They also employed some form of irrigation. Water from nearby wells were used for irrigation.
â–ªï¸ The major crops grown were wheat, rice, barley, pulses, peas, and mustard. 
â–ªï¸ Cotton cultivation in Mehrgarh dates back to 7000 years ago, during Neolithic times.

â–ªï¸ Storehouses were present in major cities such as Harappa, Mohenjodaro, and Lothal. 
â–ªï¸ Common domesticated animals included cattle, bulls, goats, and sheep.
â–ªï¸ Bull being the most frequently depicted animal on seals.

blocks.string: Agriculture

children.string:
**Religion of Harappan People:**
â–ªï¸ The people of the Harappan civilization believed in some form of religion
â–ªï¸ But there is no evidence of temple-like structures. 
â–ªï¸ Evidence of **fire altars** from Kalibangan and Lothal suggests they practiced some rituals. 
â–ªï¸ The **Great Bath** from Mohenjodaro indicates that ritual bathing might have been practiced. 
â–ªï¸ **Pot burials** found in Surkotada suggest they buried their dead in this manner. Evidence also suggests that they worshipped plants and animals.
â–ªï¸ Evidences shows that they practised tree and animal worship,
â–ªï¸ They also believed in Ghosts.

**Burial Practises of Harappan People:**
â–ªï¸ **Double burial** was found at Lothal. Burial of a male & female person in a single grave is found here.
â–ªï¸ A **graveyard** was found in Harappa. Graveyard had 57 burials in total.
â–ªï¸ **Pot Burial:** At Surkotada, in Gujurat, four pot burials were found. Pot burials contained bone ashes.

blocks.string: Religion

children.string: Around 3900 years ago, many people stopped living in the cities of the Harappan civilization.
**River dried up:** One reason might be that the rivers dried up. Without rivers, it became difficult to get water for drinking and farming.

**Deforestation:** Another reason could be deforestation. People needed wood to bake bricks and to melt copper ores. They cut down many trees for this. Also, large herds of cattle, sheep, and goats ate the plants, making it hard for the trees to grow back.

**Flood:** In some places, there were floods. Too much water from the rivers could have damaged houses and fields. However, flooding or rivers drying up can't explain why all the cities were abandoned, since these issues would only affect certain areas.
**Over grazing:** Large herds of cattle, sheep, and goats may have eaten too much grass and plants. This would have left the land bare and unable to support farming or other activities.

**Aryan invasion:** Some scholars suggest that new groups of people, like the Aryans, moved into the area. This may have caused conflicts and changes in how the cities were controlled. As a result, people might have left the big cities and moved to smaller settlements in the east and south.

**About Indus River:**
â–ªï¸ The ancient name of Jhelum was "Sindhu".
â–ªï¸ It originates from Bokharchu glacier, near Mansarovar lake, in Kailash range, in Karakoram range, Tibet.
â–ªï¸ Leh city is situated on the bank of Indus. 
â–ªï¸ From Mansarovar lake, Indus rivers runs southwards, but near the Mt. Naga Parbat, it takes southward direction. 
â–ªï¸ Indus has fiver major tributries i.e Jhelum, Chenab, Rabi, Beas and Satluj.
â–ªï¸ All the fiver major tributries i.e Jhelum, Chenab, Rabi, Beas and Satluj, joins and forms Panjnad, which then merges with Indus at Mithankot.

**Mention of Indus River in Rig Veda**
â–ªï¸ The rig veda mentions of the "sapta sindhu" means seven rivers, which are Indus and its tributries. 

**Their Ancient Names  were:**
â–ªï¸ Indus --- Sindhu
â–ªï¸ Jhelum -- Vitasta
â–ªï¸ Chenab -- Askini
â–ªï¸ Ravi -- Purushni or Iravati
â–ªï¸ Beas -- Bipasa or Vipasa ( B--B)
â–ªï¸ Satluj -- Shatadru or Shutudri (S--S)
â–ªï¸ Ghaggar -- Saraswati (it has disappeared)  

![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Fsilju_ssc%2Fpm7eDrpsF_.png?alt=media&token=500dbebf-b7d8-45c9-b4f6-4cb898801e15)

**Jhelum river:**
â–ªï¸ The ancient name of Jhelum was "Vitasta".
â–ªï¸ It originates from Verinag, in Pirpanjal range.
â–ªï¸ It flows through the Srinagar city.
â–ªï¸ Important lakes that falls on its course are: Dal lake, Wullar lake, Nigeen lake etc.

**Chenab river:**
â–ªï¸ The ancient name of Chenab was "Askini".
â–ªï¸ It originates from Baralacha pass.

**Ravi river:**
â–ªï¸ The ancient name of Ravi was "Purushni or Iravati".
â–ªï¸ It originates from Rhotang pass. (also Beas river)
---
â–ªï¸ The "Harappa" site was situated on the bank of Ravi river.

**Beas river:**
â–ªï¸ The ancient name of Beas was "Bipasa".
â–ªï¸ It originates from Rhotang pass. (also Ravi river)
â–ªï¸ It merges with Satluj river at Harike, in Punjab, India.
â–ªï¸ It is the only major tributary of Indus that originates as well as ends within India.

**Satluj river:**
â–ªï¸ The ancient name of Satluj was "Shutudri".
â–ªï¸ It originates from Mansarovar lake, in Kailash range in Tibet.
â–ªï¸ It enters India, Himachal Pradesh, through Shipkla pass. 
â–ªï¸ It is the only major tributary of Indus, that does not originates from India.

**Shoyk river:**
â–ªï¸ Shyok river is a minor tributary of Indus. 
â–ªï¸ It originates from Siachen glacier.
â–ªï¸ It flows through the Nubra valley, Ladakh and finally joins Indus in Gilgit Baldistan. 
----
â–ªï¸ Other minor tributries of Indus river are Shingo, Suru, Zanskar etc.

**Indus Water Treaty**
â–ªï¸ It was signed in 1960, between India and Pakistan
â–ªï¸ It was brokered by World Bank
â–ªï¸ It divided Indus and its tributries into two groups.
â–ªï¸ Water of Indus, Jhelum and Chenab were given to Pakistan
â–ªï¸ Water of Ravi, Beas and Satluj were given to India

**Brahmo Samaj**
â–ªï¸ Brahmo sabha was founded in 1828
â–ªï¸ It was founded by Raja Rammohan Roy, in 1828, in Calcutta.
â–ªï¸ In 1830 it was renamed as "Brahma Samaj"
â–ªï¸ Raja Rammohan Roy is also known as Father of Indian Renaissance

**Core Ideas of Brahmo Samaj**
â–ªï¸ Belief in one God (monotheism).
â–ªï¸ Rejection of idol worship and rituals.
â–ªï¸ Opposed caste system and social evils (sati, polygamy, child marriage).
â–ªï¸ Brahmo Samaj played the key role in abolition of Sati in India. 
â–ªï¸ Promoted womenâ€™s education and widow remarriage.

**Influence:**
â–ªï¸ Brahmo Samaj based its ideas on the teachings of the Upanishads.

**Arya Samaj**
â–ªï¸ Arya Samaj was founded by Swami Dayanand Saraswati in 1875 in Bombay.
â–ªï¸ Arya Samaj believed in the infallibility of the Vedas. 
â–ªï¸ Arya Samaj gave the slogan â€œBack to the Vedasâ€.

**Core Beliefs:**
â–ªï¸ Monotheism (belief in one God).
â–ªï¸ Rejection of idol worship, rituals, and priestly dominance.
â–ªï¸ Condemned caste system based on birth, but supported the caste system by occupation. 
â–ªï¸ Promoted equality of all human beings, including women.

**Social Reforms:**
â–ªï¸ Supported widow remarriage.
â–ªï¸ Opposed child marriage.
â–ªï¸ Promoted education for girls and boys alike.

** Educational Work:** 
â–ªï¸ Established Dayanand Anglo-Vedic (DAV) Schools & Colleges.

**Ramakrishna Mission**
â–ªï¸ It was founded in 1897 by Swami Vivekananda.
â–ªï¸ It was founded yo spread the teachings of Ramakrishna Paramhansa, guru of Swami Vivekananda. 
â–ªï¸ The phrase "service to man is service to God" was coined by Swami Vivekananda

**Teachings and Beliefs**
â–ªï¸ All religions lead to the same truth.
â–ªï¸ Service to man is service to God.
â–ªï¸ Promoted universal brotherhood and tolerance.
â–ªï¸ Condemned caste system and untouchability.

**Introduction**
â–ªï¸ The legislature in India is called as "Parliament".
â–ªï¸ The Parliament consists of three parts (Article 79):
(1) Upper House ( = Rajya Sabha)
(2) Lower House ( = Lok Sabha)
(3) The president.
â–ªï¸ The president is part of the parliament. 
â–ªï¸ Indian legislature is having two houses i.e upper and lower house, thus indian legislature i.e parliament is called as "bicameral legislature". 
â–ªï¸ The parlaiment, as legislative body, makes law for India in the form of Acts. 
â–ªï¸ To make a bill into act, first it has to be passed by both the houses, and then it had to get assent of the president, then only a bill becomes an act.

**Lok Sabha**
â–ªï¸ The lok sabha is the lower house of the parliament
â–ªï¸ Its strength is 550 i.e maximum 550 members.
â–ªï¸ Out of total 550 members, 530 members representing the States and 20 representing the Union Territories.
â–ªï¸ The tenure of lok sabha members is 5 years.

**Lok Sabha Speaker**
â–ªï¸ The head of the lok sabha is called as speaker.
â–ªï¸ Speaker is elected by the members of the house, from among them selves.
â–ªï¸ The tenure of the speaker is same as the members i.e 5 years.

**Rajya Sabha**
â–ªï¸ The lok sabha is the upper house of the parliament
â–ªï¸ Its strength is 250 i.e maximum 550 members
â–ªï¸ Out of 250, 238 are indirectly elected, and 12 are nominated by the president. 
â–ªï¸ The tenure of rajya sabha members is 6 years. 

**Rajya Sabha Chairman**
â–ªï¸ The head of the rajye sabha is called as chairman.
â–ªï¸ The  Vice President of India, acts as the chairman of the rajya sabha.
â–ªï¸ The tenure of the rajya sabha chairman is thus same as the vice president i.e 5 years.

**Birth of Buddha**
â–ªï¸ Buddha was born in around 563 BCE in Lumbini, Kapilavastu, (present day Nepal).
â–ªï¸ His real name was Siddharta Gautama
â–ªï¸ He belong to Kshatriya caste. 
â–ªï¸ His father name was Suddhodana, king of Sakya clan.
â–ªï¸ His mother name was Mahamaya, who died shortly after Buddha's birth.
â–ªï¸ Buddha was raised by Prajapati Gautami (Mahamayaâ€™s sister and Suddhodanaâ€™s second wife).
â–ªï¸ At the age of 16, Buddha married Yashodhara. With Yashodhara, he had a son named Rahula.

**Buddha's Search for Truth**
â–ªï¸ At the age of 29, Siddhartha Gautama left his palace in search of truth.
â–ªï¸ This event is called the Great Renunciation or Mahabhinishkramana.
â–ªï¸ The horse on which he left was named Kanthaka.
â–ªï¸ He wandered for 6 years practicing austerities and meditation.
â–ªï¸ Buddha attained enlightenment at the age of 35 in Bodh Gaya.

**Buddha became Enlightened**
â–ªï¸ Buddha attained enlightenment at the age of 35.
â–ªï¸ Under the Bodhi (Peepal) tree, near the Neranjana River, in Bodh Gaya (present-day Bihar, India).
â–ªï¸ This event is called Nirvana, marking the attainment of supreme knowledge and freedom from the cycle of birth and death.

**Buddha Giving Sermons**
â–ªï¸ After attaining enlightenment, Buddha started giving sermons.
â–ªï¸ Buddha gave his first sermon at Sarnath, Uttar Pradesh.
â–ªï¸ This event is called Dhammacakkappavattana (Turning of the Wheel of Dharma).
â–ªï¸ The sermon introduced the Four Noble Truths and the Eightfold Path, which are the core principles of Buddhism.

**Death of Buddha**
â–ªï¸ Buddha passed away at the age of 80 in Kushinagar, Uttar Pradesh, around 483 BCE. 
â–ªï¸ His death is referred to as Mahaparinirvana, marking his final release from the cycle of birth and rebirth.
â–ªï¸ Immediately After his death 1st buddhist council was held at Rajgir patronaged by king Ajatashatru of Haryanka dynasty.

â–ªï¸ The religious books of Buddhism are called as Pitakas.
â–ªï¸ The Pitakas are written in the Pali language.
â–ªï¸ Pitaka means "basket," referring to the collection of Buddha's teachings.

**Types of Pitakas:**
**1. Sutta Pitaka:** Contains the teachings and discourses of Buddha.
**2. Vinaya Pitaka:** Details the monastic code of conduct for monks and nuns.
**3. Abhidhamma Pitaka:** Focuses on Buddhist philosophy and psychology.

â–ªï¸ Abhidhamma Pitaka was compiled during the Third Buddhist Council.

**The 11 Fundamental Duties  are:**

1. To abide by the Constitution and respect its ideals, the National Flag & National Anthem.
2. To cherish and follow the noble ideals of the freedom struggle.
3. To uphold and protect sovereignty, unity & integrity of India.
4. To defend the country and render national service when called upon.
5. To promote harmony & brotherhood transcending religion, language & region, and respect women.
6. To value and preserve the rich heritage of our composite culture.
7. To protect and improve the natural environment (forests, lakes, rivers, wildlife) and show compassion for living beings.
8. To develop scientific temper, humanism & spirit of inquiry and reform.
9. To safeguard public property & abjure violence.
10. To strive towards excellence in all spheres, so that the nation constantly rises to higher levels of achievement.

11. To provide opportunities for education to children (6â€“14 years) â†’ ^^added by 86th Amendment, 2002^^

children.string:
â–ªï¸ The term â€˜preambleâ€™ refers to the introduction or preface to the Constitution. 
â–ªï¸ It contains the summary or essence of the Constitution. 
â–ªï¸ The Preamble outlines the philosophy, values, and principles that the Indian Constitution is based on, providing a concise summary of its essence.
â–ªï¸ The American Constitution was the first to begin with a Preamble. 
â–ªï¸ The idea of Preamble in the Constitution was borrowed from USA constitution.
â–ªï¸NA Palkhivala called the Preamble as the â€˜identity card of the Constitution

â–ªï¸The Preamble to the Indian Constitution is based on the Objectives Resolution. 
â–ªï¸ This resolution was drafted and introduced by Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru in the Constituent Assembly on December 13, 1946. 
â–ªï¸It was unanimously accepted by the Assembly on January 22, 1947.

â–ªï¸ Later, on the last working day of the Constituent Assembly â€” which was January 24, 1950 â€” the Objectives Resolution, with a few changes, was adopted as the Preamble to the Indian Constitution.

blocks.string: Introduction
TEXT OF THE PREAMBLE

**BORROWED FEATURES** 
â–ªï¸ The idea of preamble in the constitution was borrowed from USA constitution.
â–ªï¸ The idea of "JUSTICE" in the preamble was borrowed from USSR constitution ( or Russian revolution).
â–ªï¸ The idea of "Republic, LIBERTY, EQUALITY, FRATERNITY" in the preamble was borrowed from French constitution ( or French revolution).

children.string:
The Preamble reveals four ingredients or components:

**Source of authority of the Constitution: **
â–ªï¸ The Preamble states that the Constitution derives its authority from the people of India.

**Nature of Indian State: **
â–ªï¸ It declares India to be of a sovereign, socialist, secular democratic and republican polity.

**Objectives of the Constitution: **
â–ªï¸ It specifies justice, liberty, equality and fraternity as the objectives.

**Date of adoption of the Constitution:** 
â–ªï¸ The date November 26th 1949 is mentioned in the preamble, as on this date the Constituent Assembly adopted the constitution. 
â–ªï¸ This very date is celebrated as "**national constitution day**" in India. 
â–ªï¸ Though the constitution was **adopted** on "Nov 26 1949" but it **came into force** two months later i.e on "January 26th 1950", that is when India became a sovereign republic state.
â–ªï¸ The difference between these two dates is 61 days.

blocks.string: INGREDIENTS OF THE PREAMBLE

children.string:
Sovereign means that a country is free from external control and has full autonomy to govern itself without interference from any external authority.

**Timeline of Indiaâ€™s Sovereignty:**

**Before August 15, 1947:  **
India was a British colony and was under the direct control of the British Empire.

**From August 15, 1947, to January 26, 1950:**
India became a British Dominion after gaining independence.
During this period, India was self-governing but still recognized the British Crown as the nominal head of state.

**From January 26, 1950:**
It was on this date Indian constitution came into force and India officially becoming a sovereign, democratic, and republic state. The Constitution of India came into force, marking full independence and the establishment of India's identity as a sovereign nation.

India is described as a secular state in the Preamble to the Constitution of India, which ensures that
1. The state has no official religion.
2. All religions are treated equally by the state.
3. The government does not favor or discriminate against any religion.
The term "Secular" was added in the preamble by the 42nd Amendment 1976.

blocks.string: Meaning of Keywords

children.string:
The Indian Constitution was adopted on November 26, 1949, while the Preamble was adopted later, on January 24, 1950, which was the last working day of the Constituent Assembly. 
This raised a controversy about whether the Preamble was actually a part of the Constitution.

**Supreme Court Verdicts on the Preamble:**
**Berubari Case (1960):**
â–ªï¸ Preamble is not a part of the Constitution.
â–ªï¸ Preamble can still be used as a guiding source for interpreting the Constitution.

**Kesavananda Bharati Case (1973):**
â–ªï¸ Preamble is indeed a part of the Constitution.
â–ªï¸ it can be amended like any other provision of the Constitution, as long as such amendments do not alter the basic structure of the Constitution.

**42nd Amendment amended Preamble**
â–ªï¸ In Kesavananda Bharati Case (1973), SC held that preamble can be amended.
â–ªï¸ Preamble was amended in 1976 via 42nd Amendment Act 1976.
â–ªï¸ Through this amendment three new keywords were added in the preamble which are "SOCIALIST, SECULAR and Integrity"
â–ªï¸ So far, the Preamble has been amended only once, in 1976.

blocks.string: PREAMBLE AS PART OF THE CONSTITUTION

â–ªï¸ ^^Part-VIII (Article 239-241)^^ of the constitution deals with Union Territories (UTs).
â–ªï¸ Union Territories are directly administered by the union government.
â–ªï¸ The idea of UTs was established in 1956 by the ^^7th amendment act, 1956^^.
â–ªï¸ In 1956, the act created 6 UTs which were:
Delhi, Manipur, Tripura, Himachal Pradesh, Andaman and Nicobar Islands, and Laccadive, Minicoy, and Amindivi (now Lakshadweep) Islands
â–ªï¸ As of (Aug 2025) there are ^^8 UTs^^ in India which are:
Andaman and Nicobar Islands, Chandigarh, Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu, Delhi, Jammu & Kashmir, Ladakh, Lakshadweep, and Puducherry
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Froamprep%2FNh9msjcE7t.png?alt=media&token=aff19aad-29a3-4d72-bae4-6a6ed09139d8)

**UTs with Legislative Assembly**
â–ªï¸ The parliament can create legislature for UTs under ^^Article 239A.^^ 
â–ªï¸  The Article 239A was added via ^^14th Amendment Act, 1962^^
â–ªï¸ The Parliament under Article 239A established ^^legislature for Puducherry in 1963^^. 
â–ªï¸ In 1962 Puducherry became the first UT to have its own legislature. 
---
â–ªï¸ As of August 2025, only two UTs have legislative assembly i.e Puducherry (Article 239A) and NCT of Delhi (Article 239A)
â–ªï¸ The UT of Jammu and Kashmir, has given legislative assembly
â–ªï¸ The UT Ladakh is demanding legislative assembly. 
â–ªï¸ As of August 2025, ^^three UTs have legislative assembly^^ i.e Puducherry, NCT of Delhi and Jammu & Kashmir.

**NCT of Delhi**
â–ªï¸ In 1956, through the ^^7th Amendment Act, 1956^^, Delhi was given the status of a Union Territory.
â–ªï¸ Later, through the ^^69th Amendment Act, 1991, Article 239AA^^ was added to the Constitution, giving Delhi a ^^special status^^.
â–ªï¸ From then, Delhi is officially called the National Capital Territory (NCT) of Delhi.
â–ªï¸ Article 239AA provides Delhi with its own Legislative Assembly and Council of Ministers, headed by a Chief Minister.
â–ªï¸ The Delhi Government has control over all subjects of the State List, except three:
1. Land
2. Police
3. Public Order
â–ªï¸ In NCT of Delhi these ^^three subjects (land, police, and public order) are directly controlled by the Union Government^^.

**High Courts for UTs**
â–ªï¸ Article 241 of the Constitution gives Parliament the power to establish a High Court for any Union Territory.
â–ªï¸ As of August 2025, ^^only the NCT of Delhi has its own separate High Court^^.
â–ªï¸ The High Court of Delhi was established on 31st October, 1966
â–ªï¸ The Union Territory of Jammu & Kashmir and the Union Territory of Ladakh share a common High Court, called the High Court of Jammu & Kashmir and Ladakh.

children.string:
2. Nobody â†’ Nothing
Rule: Use "nothing" for objects or things when the subject is "nobody".
Example:
Nobody found nothing interesting in the movie.
(No person found any interesting thing.)
3. Somebody â†’ Something
Rule: Use "something" for objects or things when the subject is "somebody".
Example:
Somebody brought something for you.
(A person brought an item for you.)
4. Anybody â†’ Anything
Rule: Use "anything" for objects or things when the subject is "anybody".
Example:
Anybody can do anything if they try hard.
(Any person can accomplish any task.)
Key Points:
"Everybody," "Nobody," "Somebody," "Anybody" â†’ refer to people.
"Everything," "Nothing," "Something," "Anything" â†’ refer to things or objects.

![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Froamprep%2FGQbfMt3ey_.png?alt=media&token=edc0066d-6f81-46c9-b12f-bf89802bfc0f)

**Founder - Chandragupta Maurya (321 - 297 BC)**
â–ªï¸ Maurya empire was founded by **Chandragupta Maurya** in around 321 BC.
â–ªï¸ Chandragupta Maurya established "Maurya empire" by overthrowing Nanda dynasty.
â–ªï¸ He defeated the Dhanananda, the last ruler of Nanda dynasty.
â–ªï¸ Chandragupta Maurya was helped by **Chanakya (= Kautilya)**, who was an intelligent and politically astute Brahmin. 
â–ªï¸ **Patliputra** (present day Patna) was the capital of Maurya empire. 
â–ªï¸ Chanakya had written as book named **Arthashatra**, in Sanskrit, in which he mentioned about the different aspected of the Maurya empire. 

**Chandragupta & Jainism**
â–ªï¸ According to Jain tradition, Chandragupta Maurya adopted Jainism, abdicated his throne, and traveled to Karnataka (south India), where he died by practicing **Sallekhana** (also called **Santhara**), a ritualistic slow starvation to death. 
â–ªï¸ He was influenced by the Jain saint Bhadrabahu and spent his final years as an ascetic.

**Bindusara (297 - 273 BC )**
â–ªï¸ He was son of Chandragupta.
â–ªï¸ He is also called **Amitraghata** (Slayer of foes) or **Amitrochates** in Greek sources.
â–ªï¸ Deimachus was a Greek ambassador at his court.
â–ªï¸ He had appointed his son, Ashoka as the governor of Ujjain.
â–ªï¸ Bindusara is believed to have extended the Mauryan Empire to Mysore as well.
â–ªï¸ He was a follower of the **Ajivika sect** (an ancient heterodox tradition, like Buddhism and Jainism).

**Ashoka ( 273 - 232 BC)**
â–ªï¸ He was son of Bindusara.
â–ªï¸ He was the greatest ruler of Maurya empire.
â–ªï¸ His capital was Patliputra (present day Patna)
â–ªï¸ In 261 BC, he founght the Kaling war, and in which thousands of  people dies, and after this war Ashoke converted to buddhism. 
â–ªï¸ After this, he stoped fighting wars, and started spreading the message of buddhism all around.


â–ªï¸ At its zenith, Ashokaâ€™s empire stretched from Afghanistan in the west to Bangladesh in the east. It covered almost the whole Indian subcontinent except present Kerala and Tamil Nadu, and modern-day Sri Lanka.
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2Froamprep%2FysWQaPH4Em.png?alt=media&token=bf4dddbf-230c-4a07-9bcd-a5ded0223c7a)

**Ashoka & Kalinga war**
â–ªï¸The Kalinga war was fought in the year 261 BC. 
â–ªï¸ The Kalinga War was fought between Ashoka, the great Mauryan Emperor, and the ruler of the State of Kalinga.
â–ªï¸ It was seen as one of the most famous and the bloodiest battles in World history, as thousnds of people died in this war
â–ªï¸ In the **13th Rock Edict Ashoka** describes about the Kalinga war.

**Ashoka & Buddhism**
â–ªï¸ After the Kalinga War, Ashoka **embraced Buddhism**.
â–ªï¸ He gave up further wars, and decided to spread the message of love, peace, and non-violence. 
â–ªï¸ He converted to Buddhism and convened the **Third Buddhist Council** at Patliputra.
â–ªï¸ The **Third Buddhist Council** was held in **Pataliputra** (modern-day Patna) in **250 BCE** under the patronage of Emperor Ashoka and presided over by **Moggaliputta Tissa**.
â–ªï¸ In the Third Buddhist Council **Abhidhamma Pitaka** was compiled, which is about Buddhist philosophy.
â–ªï¸ Ashoka actively spread the message of Dhamma and even appointed special ministers called Dhamma Mahamatras to propagate it.

The Kalinga War was the pivotal event that led Emperor Ashoka to embrace Buddhism and renounce military conquest, dedicating himself to non-violence and spreading the concept of dharma (righteousness) for the rest of his reign.
((ih01EFHq8))

**Chanakya**
â–ªï¸ Other names are **Vishnugupta** and **Kautilya**.
â–ªï¸ Chanakya is also called â€˜**Indian Machiavelli**â€.
â–ªï¸ Teacher of Chandragupta Maurya, who was also his Chief Minister.
â–ªï¸ He was a teacher and scholar at Taxila. 
â–ªï¸ He was also a minister in the court of Bindusara.
â–ªï¸ He is credited to be the master strategist behind the usurping of the Nanda throne and the rise of the Mauryan Empire through his student, Chandragupta.
â–ªï¸ He wrote **Arthashastra** which mentioned about various aspects of Maurya administration.

**Comptroller and Auditor General of India (CAG)**
â–ªï¸ Constitutional post under **Article 148**.
â–ªï¸ Appoint by the president
â–ªï¸ As per Dr Ambedkar, CAG is the **most important officer in the Indian Constitution**

**State Election Commission**
â–ªï¸ Constitutional body under **Article 243**.
â–ªï¸ It is a single member body, who is appoint by the Governor of the state
â–ªï¸ It conducts local elections i.e elections of Panchayats and Municipalities
---
((4VAEyKG-X))

**GST Council**
â–ªï¸ Constitutional body under Article 279A.
â–ªï¸ Article 279A was added by 101st amendment act, 2016
â–ªï¸ Its chairman is Union Finance Minister
â–ªï¸ It has 33 members i.e from Union (2), States (28) and UTs with legislature(3).

**Finance Commission**
â–ªï¸ Constitutional body under Article 280.
â–ªï¸ It is a five member body.
â–ªï¸ Members are appointed by the President.
â–ªï¸ It recommends distribution of taxes between center and the states.

**Public Service Commissions (PSCs)**
â–ªï¸ Union-PSCs and State-PSCs are constitutional bodies
â–ªï¸ Joint-PSC is a statutory body i.e establish by the Parliament through an Act
â–ªï¸ Their role is to recruit officers for various departments in union and state governments.
---
((4VAEyKG-X))

**Election Commission of India (ECI)** 
â–ªï¸ Constitutional body under Article 324.
â–ªï¸ It is a five member body.
â–ªï¸ Members are appointed by the President.
â–ªï¸ It conducts elections of president, vice-president, lok sabha, rajya sabha, state assemblies and state councils.
â–ªï¸ The first ECI was appointed on Jan 25 1950, and thus "Jan 25" is celebrated as "national voters day" in India.

**National Commission for SCs**
â–ªï¸ Constitutional body under Article 338.
â–ªï¸ It is a five member body, One Chairperson, one Vice-Chairperson, and three other Members.
â–ªï¸ At least one of the three other members being a woman.
â–ªï¸ Members are appointed by the President.
â–ªï¸ They serve a three-year term
â–ªï¸ It deals with the welfare and safeguard of SCs in India

**National Commission for STs**
â–ªï¸ Constitutional body under Article 338A.
â–ªï¸ The Article 338A was added via  89th amendment act 2003. 
â–ªï¸ It is a five member body, One Chairperson, one Vice-Chairperson, and three other Members.
â–ªï¸ At least one of the three other members being a woman.
â–ªï¸ Members are appointed by the President.
â–ªï¸ They serve a three-year term
â–ªï¸ It deals with the welfare and safeguard of STs in India

**National Commission for OBCs**
â–ªï¸ Constitutional body under Article 338B.
â–ªï¸ The Article 338B was added via  102nd amendment act 2018. 
â–ªï¸ It is a five member body, One Chairperson, one Vice-Chairperson, and three other Members.
â–ªï¸ At least one of the three other members being a woman.
â–ªï¸ Members are appointed by the President.
â–ªï¸ They serve a three-year term
â–ªï¸ It deals with the welfare and safeguard of OBCs in India

There bodies are there who members are appoint by the Governor of the state but remove by the President. 
These bodies are:
1. State Election Commission
2. State Public Service Commission
3. State Human Rights Commission

blocks.string: Constitutional Bodies

â–ªï¸ Part-III (Article 12-35) of the constitution deals with Fundamental Rights.
â–ªï¸ They are called as fundamental rights because they are **guaranteed** rights. 
â–ªï¸ **Justiciable:** These rights are enforceable by the courts, meaning individuals can approach the judiciary if they feel their rights are being violated.
â–ªï¸ They apply universally to all citizens, irrespective of race, religion, caste, gender, or place of birth.
ğŸ”¹ Five fundamental rights are only available to Indian citizens which are: Article 15, 16, 19, 29, 30.
â–ªï¸ They are not absolute and the state can put reasonable restrictions.

â–ªï¸ The original constitution (Jan 26, 1950) has seven fundamental rights.
ğŸ”¹In 1978, the "Right to Property" was removed from Part III (Article 31) and moved to Part XII (Article 300A) by the 44th Amendment Act, 1978
â–ªï¸  Thus as of 2025, we have six fundamental rights. 

**The Six Fundamental Rights are:**
1. Right to Equality ( 14-18)
2. Right to Freedom ( 19-22)
3. Right Against Exploitation (23-24)
4. Right to Freedom of Religion ( 25-28)
5. Cultural and Educational Rights (29-30)
6. Right to Constitutional Remedies (32)

ğŸ”¹Thus at present the "Right to Property" is a constitutional right under Part XII (Article 300A) by the 44th Amendment Act, 1978.

**Right to Equality (Articles 14â€“18)**

**Article 14 â€“ Equality before Law**
â–ªï¸ All persons are equal before the law.
â–ªï¸ No one is above the law (including govt. officials).

**Article 15 â€“ No Discrimination**
â–ªï¸ No discrimination by the State on the grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth.
â–ªï¸ However, special provisions allowed for women, children, SCs, STs, and OBCs.

**Article 16 â€“ Equal Opportunity in Public Jobs**
â–ªï¸ Equal chance for all citizens in public employment.
â–ªï¸ Reservations allowed for backward classes, SCs, STs, and economically weaker sections (EWS).

**Article 17 â€“ Abolition of Untouchability**
â–ªï¸ Practice of untouchability is prohibited in any form.
â–ªï¸ Punishable offence under law.

**Article 18 â€“ Abolition of Titles**
â–ªï¸ No titles (like Raja, Maharaja, Rai Bahadur) can be given.
â–ªï¸ Exception â†’ Military & Academic titles (e.g., Doctor, Major, Professor).

**Right to Freedom ( Article 19-22)**

**Article 19 â€“ Six Fundamental Freedoms**
â–ªï¸ Every citizen has six freedoms:
1. Freedom of speech & expression
2. Freedom to assemble peacefully
3. Freedom to form associations/unions
4. Freedom to move freely throughout India
5. Freedom to reside in any part of India
6. Freedom to practice any profession or carry on any occupation, trade, or business
â–ªï¸ Restrictions possible in interest of public order, morality, security, sovereignty of India, etc.

**Article 20 â€“ Protection in Criminal Cases**
â–ªï¸ No ex-post facto law â€“ No punishment for an act that was not an offence under law when committed.
â–ªï¸ No double jeopardy â€“ Cannot be punished twice for the same offence.
â–ªï¸ No self-incrimination â€“ No person can be forced to be a witness against himself.

**Article 21 â€“ Right to Life & Personal Liberty**
â–ªï¸ No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.
â–ªï¸ Expanded by SC to include: right to privacy, clean environment, livelihood, shelter, health, speedy trial, etc.

**Article 21A â€“ Right to Education**
â–ªï¸ Free & compulsory education for children aged 6â€“14 years.
â–ªï¸ Inserted by 86th Amendment Act, 2002.

**Article 22 â€“ Protection against Arrest & Detention**
â–ªï¸ Provides rights to persons arrested.
â–ªï¸ Preventive detention allowed but with limits:
â€“ Maximum 3 months, can be extended with approval of an advisory board.
â€“ Parliament can prescribe longer periods.

**Right Against Exploitation (Articles 23â€“24)**

**Article 23 â€“ Ban on Human Exploitation**
â–ªï¸ Prohibits traffic in human beings (slavery, bonded labor, begar/forced labor).
â–ªï¸ Both the State and private individuals are prohibited from exploiting others.
â–ªï¸ The State can impose compulsory service for public purposes (e.g., military service, social service), but without discrimination.

**Article 24 â€“ Ban on Child Labour**
â–ªï¸ Prohibits employment of children below 14 years in:
â€“ factories
â€“ mines
â€“ hazardous occupations
â–ªï¸ Aim: To protect the health, safety, and dignity of children.

**Right to Freedom of Religion (Articles 25â€“28)**

**Article 25 â€“ Freedom of Religion for Individuals**
â–ªï¸ Every person has freedom of conscience.
â–ªï¸ Right to profess, practice, and propagate any religion.
â–ªï¸ Subject to: public order, morality, health, and other fundamental rights.

**Article 26 â€“ Freedom for Religious Communities**
â–ªï¸ Religious groups/denominations can:
- Establish and maintain religious institutions.
- Manage their own religious affairs.
- Own and acquire property.
- Administer property according to law.

**Article 27 â€“ No Religious Taxes**
â–ªï¸ No person can be forced to pay taxes for the promotion or maintenance of any religion.

**Article 28 â€“ Religious Instruction in Educational Institutions**
â–ªï¸ No religious instruction can be given in institutions wholly funded by the State.
â–ªï¸ In institutions managed by the State but established under an endowment or trust, religious instruction is allowed.
â–ªï¸ Students cannot be forced to attend religious instruction or worship

**Cultural and Educational Rights (Articles 29â€“30)**

**Article 29 â€“ Protection of Interests of Minorities**
â–ªï¸ Any section of citizens having a distinct language, script, or culture has the right to conserve it.
â–ªï¸ No citizen can be denied admission into any state-run or state-aided educational institution on grounds of religion, race, caste, language, or any of them.

**Article 30 â€“ Right of Minorities to Establish and Administer Institutions**
â–ªï¸ All religious and linguistic minorities have the right to establish and administer educational institutions of their choice.
â–ªï¸ State cannot discriminate in granting aid to minority educational institutions.
â–ªï¸ This ensures minorities can preserve their culture and identity through education.

**Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32)**
â–ªï¸ Article 32 provides the right to move the Supreme Court for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.
â–ªï¸ Dr. B. R. Ambedkar called it the "Heart and Soul" of the Constitution.
â–ªï¸ It makes Fundamental Rights enforceable and justiciable.
â–ªï¸ Both Supreme Court (Art. 32) and High Courts (Art. 226) can issue writs.
â–ªï¸ This right acts as a guarantee against violation of Fundamental Rights.

**Five Writs under Article 32**

**Habeas Corpus** 
â–ªï¸ â€œProduce the bodyâ€ 
â–ªï¸ Issued to release a person unlawfully detained.

**Mandamus** 
â–ªï¸ Means â€œWe Commandâ€
â–ªï¸ Issued to direct a public authority to perform its duty.

**Prohibition** 
â–ªï¸ Issued by a higher court to a lower court to stop it from exceeding its jurisdiction.

**Certiorari** 
â–ªï¸ Issued by a higher court to transfer or quash the order of a lower court.

**Quo Warranto** 
â–ªï¸ Means  â€œBy what authorityâ€ 
â–ªï¸ Issued to check the legality of a person holding a public office.

**History of Making of Constituent Assembly**
â–ªï¸ M.N. Roy,  in 1934 for the first time suggested for making a constitution assembly to draft a constitution for India. 
â–ªï¸ Then it was Jawaharlal Nehru, who in Lucknow session of INC 1936, first time officially demand for a Constituent Assembly to draft a constitution.
â–ªï¸ The Britishers for the first time agreed to form Constituent Assembly  in "August Offer 1940" with mainly Indians.
â–ªï¸ The Britishers for the first time agreed to form Constituent Assembly  in "Cripps Mission 1946" with majority Indians
â–ªï¸ But the Constituent Assembly was finally established in 1946 as per the recommendation of "Cabinet Mission Plan, 1946". As per which the "Constituent Assembly" had 389 members.

**Dec 09 1946:** 
â–ªï¸ The members of the Constituent Assembly met for the first time.
â–ªï¸ Total 299 members were there, as Muslim League boycotted the session.
â–ªï¸ Dr Sachiananda Sinha was appointed as temporary(provisional) president.

**Dec 11 1946:** 
â–ªï¸ Election for the president and vice-president of the constituent assembly was held.
â–ªï¸ **Dr Rajandra Prasad** was elected as the president.
â–ªï¸ There were two vice presidents of the constituent assembly. *H C Mukharjee** and **V.T. Krishnamachari** were elected as the vice-presidents. They were elected to assist Dr. Rajendra Prasad, who was the president of the constituent assembly.
â–ªï¸ B. N Rao was the constitutional advisor of the constituent assembly.

**Dec 13 1946:** 
â–ªï¸ Jawaharlal Nehru moved the "objective resolution" in the assembly.
â–ªï¸ "Objective resolution" was passed unanimously in the assembly on Jan 22 1947.
â–ªï¸ Later on the last working day of the constituent assembly i.e Jan 24 1950, this objective resolution was adopted as preamble.

**July 22 1947:** 
â–ªï¸  The national flag was adopted by the constituent assembly.

**Nov 26 1949:**
â–ªï¸ On this day the constituent assembly adopted the constitution, and this constitution later came info effect on Jan 26, 1950.
â–ªï¸ This date "Nov 26 1949" is mentioned in the preamble of the constitution.
â–ªï¸ This day i.e "Nov 26" is celebrated as the "constitution day" in India. 
â–ªï¸ "Dr B R Ambedkar" was known as the "father of Indian Constitution"

**Jan 24 1950:**
â–ªï¸ It was the last working day of the constituent assembly.
â–ªï¸ On this day the Constituent Assembly adopted three things i.e national anthem, national song and preamble.
â–ªï¸ The "objective resolution", with some modifications, adopted as the the preamble of the constitution.

**January 26, 1950 â€“ When India became Republic**
â–ªï¸  On this day, the Constitution of India came into effect.
â–ªï¸  Dr. Rajendra Prasad, the President of the Constituent Assembly, took oath as the first President of India.
â–ªï¸ India thus became a Republic, and hence 26th January is celebrated as Republic Day every year.
â–ªï¸ The President of India is the Head of the State. A country where the Head of State is an elected representative is known as a Republic.
â–ªï¸ Between 15th August 1947 (Independence) and 26th January 1950, Indiaâ€™s Head of State was the Governor-General, and India functioned as a British Dominion.
â–ªï¸ From 26th January 1950, the President replaced the Governor-General as the elected Head of State, making India a Sovereign and Republic State.
---
â–ªï¸ Dr. Rajendra Prasad was the first president of India.
â–ªï¸ Dr. Rajendra Prasad was the only president of India having two terms (1950-55-60).

**Aug 15, 1947 When India Got Independence**
â–ªï¸ India got Independence.

â–ªï¸ Before "Aug 15, 1947", India was a British Colony, and the governor-general was appointed by British crown. 
â–ªï¸ Last governor-general of British India was Lord Mountbatten.
----
â–ªï¸ After "Aug 15, 1947" India became a "British Dominion"
â–ªï¸ Free India had two governor-generals.
â–ªï¸ First "governor-general" of free India was Lord Mountbatten
â–ªï¸ Second "governor-general" of free India was Rajagopalachari, who was also the only and first Indian governor general. 
-----
â–ªï¸ After "Jan 26, 19450" India became a "Sovereign and Republic" state, 
â–ªï¸ President replaced governor-general as the head of the state.
â–ªï¸ Dr Rajandra Prasad took oath as the first president of India.

**DRAFTING COMMITEE**
â–ªï¸ Drafting committee was the most important committee of the constituent assembly.
â–ªï¸ It has 7 members.
â–ªï¸ Dr B.R. Ambedkar was the chairman of the drafting committee.
â–ªï¸ Dr B.R. Ambedkar is also known as "father of the Indian constitution" or "architect of the indian constitution"
